title: Pet bans in strata could end in Supreme Court
text:
“The blanket ban has been in force since the inception of the strata scheme in 1997,” the memo says. “A delay of another month or two pending the outcome of the appeal would be immaterial in that context.”

Merely lodging an appeal doesn’t negate the ruling so, until there is a temporary “stay” of the Tribunal decision (the committee has already applied for one), it may be that there was in effect no pet by-law in place at all.

That theoretically gave determined pet lovers a window of a couple of weeks in which to welcome a fur-baby into their lives, provided they were prepared to fight for the right to keep it if the pet ban was reinstated.

And it could be that the very real possibility of months if not years of tribunal hearings, appeals and, ultimately, cases in the Supreme Court is what concerns the committee most.

All that aside, a fundamental question lies at the heart of this dispute. To paraphrase, NCAT ruled that a blanket ban on all pets allowed for no circumstances under which companion animals might be allowed, and was therefore harsh and oppressive.

The residents who challenged the by-law had argued that recent changes to strata law showed the government wanted apartment residents to be able to have pets.

One thrust of the committee’s appeal – apart from legal arguments – is likely to be that not allowing a building to ban pets is also unreasonable, because it impinges on the rights of people who want to live in blocks where pets are not allowed, for personal, health, cultural, or religious reasons.

The greatest danger for the anti-pet lobby is that the Appeals Tribunal could rule that, yes, they may have a by-law restricting pets – but not the one they had. And, with pro-pet numbers growing, the chances of them getting the 75 per cent vote required to pass a new one may be slimmer than a chihuahua’s diamante collar.

Advertisement

What does this mean for the rest of NSW and, indeed, Australia? This one could go all the way to the Supreme Court, setting legal precedents for the state and elsewhere.

Would anyone really take it that far? With all the heat already in the dispute, we should recall the phrase that some lawyers love to hear: “It’s a matter of principle.”

Jimmy Thomson edits the strata living advice website flat-chat.com.au. States have different strata laws.
description: An overturning of a pet ban in a Kings Cross apartment block could have repercussions for the whole country.
